importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the arrest and the incident's public disclosure reflects a critical moment in law enforcement response to active threat warnings, highlighting real-time coordination between local and federal agencies.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of Cagle's arrival at the airport and subsequent arrest underscores the urgency of rapid law enforcement action in preventing a potential mass casualty event.

keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, a 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after being tipped off by his family that he planned to shoot up the airport via a social media livestream.
Cagle was found in possession of an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the airport terminal.
The incident was averted due to early warning from family members, who alerted law enforcement after noticing threatening social media posts.

Cagle has been charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a felon.
Police used surveillance and body-camera footage to confirm Cagle's presence and conduct the arrest, which was carried out with the aid of a photo provided by family members.
The case highlights the role of community vigilance in preventing violent acts, especially when individuals with mental health challenges express dangerous intentions.
Federal authorities are investigating how Cagle obtained the firearm, which law enforcement confirms he was not legally permitted to possess.
The mayor of Atlanta and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem expressed gratitude that the attack was stopped before any casualties occurred.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Billy Joe Cagle, a 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted law enforcement that he had planned to shoot up the world’s busiest airport on a social media livestream. Police discovered an AR-15 rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal. Authorities say Cagle had expressed violent intentions and was in possession of a firearm, which he was not legally allowed to own. The incident was averted due to early warning from family members, prompting swift action by Atlanta police and federal coordination. Cagle has been charged with terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, and possession of firearms by a felon and a felon in commission. The case underscores the importance of community vigilance, mental health awareness, and the role of social media in disseminating dangerous threats.
title: Man Arrested at Atlanta Airport After Family Warns of Shooting Threat on Social Media
